White chicks is one of the most hilarious movies that has ever existed. Actors Shawn and Marlon Wayans play FBI agents in this movie that came out in 2004. Directed by, Keenen Ivory Wayans, this movie has a lot of crude jokes but is very funny. Other actors seen in this film are Brittney daniels, Terry Crews, Jaime King, John Heard, and many more. This film has some extreme bathroom humor and side plots.
 In the beginning of the movie, FBI agents, Kevin and Marcus start off by messing up a drug bust, they are on thin ice with their boss, Chief Gordon (played by Frankie Faison). When a new case opens up, Kevin and Marcus want on it. The case is about two rich sisters, Brittany and Tiffany Wilson, who have a suspected kidnapper that is after their money. Kevin and Marcus get on the case to pick the girls up from the airport and end up getting run off the road by a trucker and the sisters get a fat lip and a gash on their noses. Refusing to go to their weekend away at the Hamptons with their faces looking like that, Marcus and Kevin hire a geek squad to transform them into the sisters. While the real Wilson sisters are at a hotel in New York, Marcus and Kevin fool everyone that they are really the sisters.
  I thought the jokes were hilarious and the movie had some romance, action, and comedy in it, which in my opinion, is the perfect combination. The thing that stuck out to me the most in this movie was how well they guys did convincing everyone that they were the sisters. I know it's a movie and all, but I feel like you would just be able to tell and suspect it. I mean, maybe that is part of the humor of the movie.
 The plot of White Chicks was really good. I cared about what happened to the characters and certain things kept drawing me and focusing me on the movie. In one part of the movie, Terry Crews keeps bidding on one of the sisters to go on a date and ended up bidding 50,000 dollars, which had me on the edge of my seat during this process. I thought that the acting in the film was excellent; I am a huge fan of the movie and thought the jokes and humour of the movie were hilarious. The story itself was just so unrealistic, but I think that is what made the movie funnier. I also think that they way the movie was shot also was real good for being a movie shot in 2004. The movie was filmed in British Columbia, and parts of the Hamptons. The scenery and places that certain scenes were shot were also very pretty. The Hamptons have gorgeous houses and beaches.
 In conclusion, I thought that this movie was a really good and would recommend watching it, only if you like crude, a little racist, and rude jokes. I think this movie was really funny and got through the plot unlike some movies that have multiple plots and don't even get through them. This movie was funny, sad, and a little romantic, but also a really great movie.

2004 saw the release of a Wayans Brothers buddy comedy starring Marlan and Shawn Wayans, younger brothers and partners of their famous oldest brother, Keenan Ivory Wayans, who pioneered in the 1990s with In Living Color on the Fox Network.  Since the end of their sketch comedy show, the Wayans brothers went on to produce a variety of raunchy comedies which are lite on story but fun for the audiences.  Despite it's mostly negative reviews, this film has gone on to become a sort of cult classic.  Firstly, this is not Oscar material.  If you think this could be Oscar material (outside of the special effects make up), then there are some serious issues at work.  Wayans Brothers movies are full of racial, sexual, gender and toilet humor, sort of but not really "guy movies".

Two FBI agent brothers, Marcus and Kevin, have blundered a drug bust in a convenient store.  Their supervisor gives them another chance at remaining in the agency by assigning them a babysitting job.  The Wilson sisters (a thinly veiled fictional characterization of the Hilton Sisters) were coming in for a big weekend in the Hamptons and there is a kidnapping threat against them.  On the way to their Hamptons hotel, they get into a car accident that leaves the Wilson sisters with bumps and scrapes that leaves them too insecure to be seen.  Not wanting to loose their jobs, Marcus and Kevin call in the special FBI make up teams (if such a thing exists) to make them up into the Wilson sisters and they will pose as them for the weekend.  A variety of screwball comedy antics ensue as they meet with Brittney and Tiffany's friends and attempt to play wealthy young white women, the advances of a professional football player, Latrell (played by Terry Crews in his wonderful comic turn), attempting to identify the kidnappers, Marcus's suspicious wife chasing after him, and the two rival sisters attempting to thwart their social success.

While this movie is far from superior and has obvious flaws (their putting the make up on instantly rather than the hours upon hours it took to get it right behind the scenes, all around them seem to have no idea these two look a little odd, etc.), this is a good time in seeing them attempt to do a lot with so little.  Have a good laugh at their antics and physical comedy.  It's a good time.

When watching White Chicks viewers will have a good time if they do not watch the movie with a critical analysis of reality. With a plot of two African American F.B.I agents Marcus and Kevin (actors: Marlon and Shawn Wayans) going undercover at the Hamptons as two young white socialites, Tiffany and Brittany Wilson, the movie can be judged from the get go because of the prosperous idea of an African American man dressing and passing as a white female socialite. I encourage looking past the twisted actuality, so that the movie can be enjoyed as is; a comedy.
 As the F.B.I. agents discover that they will need to go undercover as white females, they call in a makeup team to make them look the part. Here is where there should not be a critical analysis of reality, because for it is obvious that Marcus and Kevin do not look vaguely like the Wilson sisters. Nor do they even look like a real women considering the immobilizing rubber prosthetics used. It is hard to imagine that anyone at the Hamptons who knows the Wilson sisters would believe the undercover agents to be them, and it is hard to look past the visuals. The performances given make up for the shoddy makeup jobs.
 The performances are overall quite worth noting. It takes a lot for a man to dress up in womens clothes and act feminine, and the Wayans brothers gave it all they had. If it was from walking in high heels to wearing mini skirts and wigs, the brothers did it all. Terry Crews, who plays Latrell Spencer, becomes infatuated with who he thinks to be Tiffany Wilson (Marlon Wayans.) During his performance, Crews give emotion to his character and puts his own twist on what Latrell Spencer should act like. The actors/actresses become the character they are portraying, and this makes for believable acting.
 Overall the movie White Chicks is a quotable one-liners kind of comedy that leaves open minded viewers laughing. When I say open minded viewers I mean those that will look past the noticeable quirks and enjoy the raw comedy and plot. This is a comedy, but it also provides action, suspense, and romance and ultimately what is the purpose of comical movies? Not to be exact reality. Movies are meant to entertain viewers, even if that means being ridiculous.

This is my only review - I've not had the inspiration to write one but I cannot stop watching this movie. I find the absurdity hilarious - including the ridiculously unbelieveable aspects of two black men dressing up as spoiled society chicks and not being called out by their big hands and feet, their masculine mannerisms. This takes one back to the comedy of Abbott and Costello, Milton Berle, even Monty Python, etc. However, I find this so much more funny and original (with the exception of Monty Python, who were the greatest at hilarious absurdity). My favorite scenes are the dance-off (so hilarious and well done), the restaurant fart scene, the face off "your mother" jokes, the bathroom scene, and the take off on "One Thousand Miles" - really hilarious. I read all the negative comments and don't find this movie racist at all (and I'm white). It is a situation comedy in the mode of Bosom Buddies - two guys passing as women so far removed from themselves, they go into outrageous character.

The movie was so entertaining that I didn't care about the sub-plot of the kidnappings. I just wanted to see more scenes of Marlon and Shawn - very good comedians, especially Marlon. I'm not a movie buff and have a hard time having my attention focused on anything too long - this movie was able to keep me at attention and wanting more.

Every bad movie has to have one good side about them, and this one had a name: Terry Crews.  Maybe it's because of his recent rise from "Everybody Hates Chris", a bit role in "Click", and the Old Spice commercials, but I kind of like his character as a wealthy basketball player who's hitting on one on the Wilson sisters, who's really Marlon Wayans in disguise.  Seeing him go nuts trying to win a 'girl's' heart as well as him singing a Vanessa Carlton song was entertaining, and outside that one scene regarding a lot of farting, he's pleasant to watch.

Although, I might be making such a statement as a desperate attempt to find anything positive about this film.  "White Chicks" is the type of film in which one looks at the movie cover and realize this is a bad idea.  The jokes are stale, predictable, and a little bit offensive such as the first scene where the Wayans bros. dress up as Hispanic clerks and overblown their acting for far too long; some parts of the humor rely on being gross, which has never been good.  The make-up on the fake heiresses is monstrous and the characters are too dense to notice the disguises, even the FBI who should've easily noticed the difference between the fake and real heiresses, the FBI that Shaun and Marlon's characters are working under and part of a secret operation that their superiors didn't know; also, I find it hard to be that the brothers, when normal, can reapply such an elaborate make-up in less than 30 seconds.  Even more insipid is the reporter, who's involved in a cliche sub-plot where Shaun Wayans' character pretends to be rich to get her attention, and she must not be good at her job if she didn't notice the blatant lies like Shaun being attacked by a guard dog in what his character called his own house.

Even with such flaws, this movie manage to make an impression on me.  It's not a funny impression nor a satisfying one, but it made me gasped in horror for almost the entire duration.  As grotesque as the whole premise is, I just couldn't look away.

NOTE: This review refers to the unrated version.

I guess the Wayans Brothers didn't realize that the "men in drag" premise is now old and tiresome. I mean, take a look at Some Like It Hot, Tootsie, or even The Rocky Horror Picture Show. The same premise was used, but plenty of brand new elements were added. White Chicks also has some new elements (placing two African-Americans under lots of makeup, and turning them into blond female teenagers), but it just doesn't work. The disguises of both Shawn & Marlon Wayans are so grotesquely ugly that that it's more painful than funny to look at. Just take a look at the front side of this DVD case, and try not to cringe at the mere sight of it. But it's not just the horrible makeup, but it's also the unfunny jokes that make this movie a big disappointment. There were only few jokes that made me laugh; those that were unfunny felt very forced, and these make up 109 out of the entire 110 minutes of the film. The Wayans Brothers are much better than this. They've made the first Scary Movie & Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in the Hood, both of which I enjoyed immensely. White Chicks fails as a comedy, but it's hardly the worst I have ever seen. The Hot Chick makes this one look like Spaceballs.

Grade: D

Hollywood Shuffle, I'm Gonna Get You Sucka, In Living Color, A Low Down Dirty Shame, the Wayans Brothers, and Waynehead were brilliant pieces of Black satire that showcased the tremendous talent the family had for humor. With this movie and Little Man it seems like they've lost their way.

Study these projects and pick apart the jokes. Take a trip back to the comedy clubs in New York. Talk to some people. Reconnect with the roots of your comedy. I happened to finally catch up with Zoolander the other day and it shows that you can combine a thriller plot with comedy to good effect.  Here the rather po-faced thriller element totally fails to mesh with the comedy, & the conventional romance sub-plot is a yawn.  I don't mind things being ludicrous, but they must have some sort of internal logic to them.  At one point there's a dance-off competition where our heroes throw down with all manner of fancy moves.  Who knew that all FBI agents were such good dancers?

I actually liked the fact they looked kind of hideous in drag & make-up but still everyone believed they were the real girls.  But even there construction was slack: in a scene where one agent is trying on a dress one of the real girls comes into the dressing room to help 'her' change.  The real girl wrenches the guy's underpants up into a thong style, leading to him whooping in pain.  What's slack is that she doesn't notice that this 'white chick' has a brown ass.

Maybe I zoned out right at the start (a very unfunny stakeout-gone-wrong sequence) but who was the guys' special friend who had all this amazing make-up & a team to apply it?

Another example of general laziness is that the 'girls' never worry about wigs or make-up going awry (not even when break-dancing on their heads) so the suspense of being in disguise is mostly thrown away.

It seems pointless to point out all the gaping holes in the plot but one example would be when one of the agents' wives thinks he is cheating on her.  Now he could tell her the truth: that he's undercover.  But instead he doesn't, leading to more senseless complications generated, I suspect, by a desire to give the sistas a slightly higher profile in the movie.

This could have been a really funny film.  It could have made some sharp points about race & gender.  It could - like the Wayans brothers' other flicks - have been a fun send-up of (in this case) drag movies.  Instead it was a chore.  You know when you find that you've wandered off to the bathroom or kitchen without pausing the dvd player?  This is one of those.  I got the feeling someone came up with the idea & then imported the Wayans brothers to make it into an appealing package - promotion-wise, that is. To me, it's just the boys laughing at the human ability to create issues out of irrelevant things like race and gender.

Talented as the Wayans are, the superb Terry Crews almost steals the show as Latrell Spencer, right down to his Eighties pickup lines, robotic dancing and his singing of Vanessa Carlton's A Thousand Miles, which appears more than once in the movie. The most entertaining appearance was when the 'girls' and their three friends are heading out in an exotic open-top car and the song comes on the radio; which they sing along with, before switching to a 50 Cent rap number.

Stage actress  Jennifer Carpenter again grabs the limelight in a brilliant performance as the weight/body image obsessed Lisa. The scene in which 'Shawn' is watching her change into a stunning black outfit is hilarous, but also undesrcores the point that many women who are already slim and beautiful have poor self-image due to all manner of insane social pressures.

This is probably the ultimate guys dressing as gals movie in so far as it is gutsy enough to try some very experimental makeup techniques, of the kind normally reserved for Alien characters in Sci Fi movies. While the guys don't actually end up looking much like the Wilson sisters, if you can suspend your disbelief for long enough you can just enjoy the crazy events as they unfold.

It's a complete BabeFest too, right down to the inevitable Bad Girls played by the stunning Jaime King and Brittany Daniel. The Making Of and other Features are superb and give you a sense of the fun the whole cast had making this movie.

Nope this isn't High Art, but then it was never supposed to be.

I am usually a fan of men-in-drag comedies. But for some reason "White Chicks" just did NOT hit the spot. Perhaps because the plot was so completely ludicrous (two black FBI agents masquerading as white women complete with latex costumes and wigs), or perhaps because the jokes were just not that funny (Such as the scene at the beginning where the Wayan brothers were pretending to be Puerto Ricans and kept uttering silly pseudo-Spanish phrases), which, quite frankly embarrassed me rather than amused me.

If I could wrap my mind around the whole idea that two FBI agents MIGHT be persuaded to handle the cases these two were assigned to, there's the costumes themselves. They looked quite painful. Demon-blue contacts, and fake botox-smile faces quite frankly were scary rather than funny. I guess I just can't get into a film where the two actors look like they are being tortured by odd makeup.

There were a few funny scenes, like the rich ball star who kept hitting on one of the agents, and the cute little fuzzy dog. But these were few and far between.

Overall, I found White Chicks about as funny as a funeral. If you want to see a few good humorous movies with the same theme rent the Birdcage, Tootsie, or Some Like it Hot. Two stars for an honest effort....It just didn't work for me.

I was not expecting much from the movie White Chicks. In fact, the Wayans brothers make two extraordinarily ugly women and the commercial left me wondering if I really wanted to see this DVD.

I also had to dig deep to believe that the brothers disguised as women would fool anybody, but that is the beauty of fiction versus reality. Sometimes you just roll with it.

I have to confess that I would have given this movie a C or C+ if it weren't for two key scenes. Both had to do with bodily functions, so I am revealing a bit of my demented guy humor, but the scene with Marlon in the bathroom rivals that of Finch in American Pie. Marlon's scene in the restaurant reminded me of the family in Eddie Murphy's The Nutty Professor.

So take note film directors and screenwriters: if you want to score a laugh with me, insert the right amount of fart and poop scenes/jokes, and I will bump my grade up by at least  a letter or number.

Directed by Keenan Ivory Wayans and starring his two hilarious brothers, Marlon and Shawn, there are so many silly moments it will keep you in stitches. Marlon and Shawn are FBI agents who begin by messing up a stake out in a convenience store only to embark on another case in which they must pose as two rich heiresses in order to protect them from a kidnapping. Needless to say it sounds impossible for two handsome black men to suddenly become two likable white chicks but somehow the makeup artists manage to almost pull it off. While the initial gag rests in the fact that men are attempting to act like two cute women the true gags come in the surrounding material, with an excellent cast of comedians pulling it all off with brilliance.

Marlon and Shawn Wayans are truly funny in their roles as rich white chickies, they perfect the mannerisms and accents of spoiled "valley girls" while retaining just enough of their bumbling machismo to make the act even funnier. The reference to botok and silicon only makes their plastic made up faces all the more believable because we all see enough of those zombie women running around to believe a frozen cosmetic face works in our society. Surrounding the brothers is a great cast of characters all playing up the snobbish idea of life as a rich white Hamptonite complete with shopping tips (wear open toed shoes if you have a size 14 foot and buy a 12!), cosmetic slumber parties, valley girl music and Prada, Prada, Prada. The funniest character in this film however is played by Terry Crews, as basketball player Latrell Spencer, who has an appetite for rich white meat. With every stereotypical slap presented Crews just plays along and does so brilliantly and he shines during a scene where he serenades his date with a very frilly white chick song!

This movie is great for a day of laughing, at yourself and others. It is silly and meant to just be entertaining. The true creativity in this film comes exactly from the imperfections, something we all have but too many of us try to cover up under layers of plastic at least the Wayans can still smile and laugh under theirs.
